natural problem: I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have?
natural solution: The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem outfit_choices:
fixes shirts pants hats total_choices :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "total_choices = shirts * pants * hats - shirts"
shows  "total_choices = 210"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have? The final Answer is 210
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem outfit_choices:
fixes shirts pants hats total_choices :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "total_choices = shirts * pants * hats - shirts"
shows  "total_choices = 210"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You have 6 shirts, 6 pants, and 6 hats to choose from. How many different outfit combinations can you make if you must leave out one shirt? The final answer is 210.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
shows  "card {outfit. outfit = (sh, p, h) \<and> sh \<in> {1..shirts} \<and> p \<in> {1..pants} \<and> h \<in> {1..hats} \<and> (sh \<noteq> p \<or> sh \<noteq> h \<or> p \<noteq> h)} = 210"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have? The final Answer is 210
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
shows  "card {outfit. outfit = (sh, p, h) \<and> sh \<in> {1..shirts} \<and> p \<in> {1..pants} \<and> h \<in> {1..hats} \<and> (sh \<noteq> p \<or> sh \<noteq> h \<or> p \<noteq> h)} = 210"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 6 different shirts, 6 different pants, and 6 different hats. How many possible outfits can be made such that at least two of the three items (shirt, pant, hat) are different? The final answer is 210.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
and outfits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall>s p h. outfits s p h = (if s = p \<and> p = h then 0 else 1)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(s, p, h). outfits s p h) {(s, p, h). s \<in> {1..shirts} \<and> p \<in> {1..pants} \<and> h \<in> {1..hats}} = 210"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have? The final Answer is 210
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
and outfits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall>s p h. outfits s p h = (if s = p \<and> p = h then 0 else 1)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(s, p, h). outfits s p h) {(s, p, h). s \<in> {1..shirts} \<and> p \<in> {1..pants} \<and> h \<in> {1..hats}} = 210"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a wardrobe, there are 6 shirts, 6 pants, and 6 hats. An outfit consists of one shirt, one pant, and one hat. However, an outfit is not allowed if the shirt, pant, and hat all have the same index (e.g., shirt 1, pant 1, and hat 1). How many different outfits can be created given these conditions? The final answer is 210.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "outfits x y z = (x * y * z) - x"
shows  "outfits shirts pants hats = 210"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have? The final Answer is 210
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "outfits x y z = (x * y * z) - x"
shows  "outfits shirts pants hats = 210"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: You have 6 shirts, 6 pants, and 6 hats. Calculate the number of outfits you can make, excluding the option of not wearing a shirt. The final answer is 210 outfits.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "distinct_colors (shirts, pants, hats) = (\<lambda>(s, p, h). s \<noteq> p \<or> p \<noteq> h)"
shows  "card {outfit | outfit. distinct_colors outfit} = 210"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have? The final Answer is 210
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 6"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "distinct_colors (shirts, pants, hats) = (\<lambda>(s, p, h). s \<noteq> p \<or> p \<noteq> h)"
shows  "card {outfit | outfit. distinct_colors outfit} = 210"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 6 shirts, 6 pants, and 6 hats, each with different colors. An outfit is considered distinct if at least two of the three clothing items have different colors. How many distinct outfits can be made? The final answer is 210.
